test_cases.issue_description: Customer is unable to change their plan immediately through the online portal and is forced to wait until the next billing cycle
test_cases.test_scenario: Test the online portal's plan change functionality to ensure it allows for immediate plan changes with prorated charges
preconditions: Customer has an active account
Customer has used most of their data for the current cycle
Customer attempts to change their plan through the online portal
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the customer portal with a test account
Step 2: Navigate to the plan change section
Step 3: Attempt to change the plan to a higher tier with more data
Step 4: Verify if the system allows for an immediate plan change with a prorated charge
Step 5: Verify if the system provides an alternative option to purchase a data add-on
test_cases.expected_result: The system should allow the customer to change their plan immediately with a prorated charge or offer an alternative option to purchase a data add-on
test_cases.actual_issue: The system does not allow for immediate plan changes and forces the customer to wait until the next billing cycle
edge_cases: Test with accounts that have multiple lines
Test with accounts that have pending payments or other restrictions
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration, unnecessary support calls, and potential loss of business due to inability to meet customer needs in a timely manner

test_cases.issue_description: Port request gets stuck due to missing middle initial in customer's name
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the web portal's device activation form collects all required information, including middle initials, to prevent port request delays
preconditions: Customer has a Verizon account with a middle initial in their name
Customer has purchased a new phone from the Total Wireless website
test_steps: Step 1: Attempt to activate a new device on the web portal
Step 2: Enter first and last name, but not middle initial, in the activation form
Step 3: Enter correct Verizon account information
Step 4: Submit the port request
Step 5: Verify that the port request is not stuck due to missing middle initial
test_cases.expected_result: The web portal's device activation form should either collect the middle initial or handle cases where the customer's name has a middle initial on their Verizon account
test_cases.actual_issue: The current form design does not account for middle initials, causing port requests to get stuck
environmental_dependencies: Device used to access web portal
edge_cases: Test with different types of names (e.g. names with suffixes, prefixes)
Test with different Verizon account information formats
test_cases.customer_impact: Service delays and customer dissatisfaction due to incomplete or inaccurate information collection

test_cases.issue_description: Customer is charged for international roaming without notification when phone connects to a stronger foreign tower near the border
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the system correctly notifies customers when their phone connects to a foreign tower for roaming, especially in border areas
preconditions: Customer has an active international roaming plan
Customer is near the US-Mexico border
Foreign tower signal is stronger than US tower signal
test_steps: Step 1: Enable international roaming on the customer's account
Step 2: Simulate the customer's phone connecting to a foreign tower near the border
Step 3: Verify that the customer receives a roaming notification or warning
Step 4: Check the customer's usage details to ensure accurate roaming charges are applied
test_cases.expected_result: Customer receives a notification or warning when their phone connects to a foreign tower for roaming, and accurate roaming charges are applied to their account
test_cases.actual_issue: Customers are not receiving notifications when their phone connects to a foreign tower, resulting in unexpected roaming charges
environmental_dependencies: Mobile device with international roaming capabilities
Strong foreign tower signal near the US-Mexico border
edge_cases: Customer is in an area with weak US tower signal
Customer has a phone with automatic network selection enabled
Customer has a limited or blocked international roaming plan
test_cases.customer_impact: Unexpected roaming charges and lack of transparency can lead to customer frustration and mistrust

test_cases.issue_description: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page for device purchase
test_cases.test_scenario: Verify that pricing information is consistent and clearly indicates any conditions for promotional prices
preconditions: User is logged in to their account
User has an existing line to upgrade
User navigates to the product page for a device with conditional pricing
test_steps: Step 1: Verify the price displayed on the product page
Step 2: Proceed to checkout with the device in the cart
Step 3: Verify the price displayed on the checkout page
Step 4: Check for any conditional pricing information (e.g. 'price with new line activation') on both the product and checkout pages
test_cases.expected_result: The price displayed on the product page and checkout page should be the same, or any differences should be clearly explained with conditional pricing information
test_cases.actual_issue: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page due to unclear conditional pricing information
edge_cases: Test with different types of devices and pricing plans
Test with new line activation vs. existing line upgrade
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer time wasted, loss of trust due to misleading pricing information

test_cases.issue_description: Plan change buttons are non-responsive for customers with multiple add-ons
test_cases.test_scenario: Test plan change functionality for customers with multiple add-ons
preconditions: Customer has an account with multiple add-ons (e.g. international calling and mobile hotspot)
Customer is using a supported browser (e.g. Chrome)
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the customer portal with a test account that has multiple add-ons
Step 2: Navigate to the plan change page
Step 3: Click on the plan options buttons
Step 4: Verify that the plan change feature responds as expected
test_cases.expected_result: The plan change buttons respond correctly, allowing the customer to change their plan
test_cases.actual_issue: The plan change buttons are non-responsive, preventing the customer from changing their plan
edge_cases: Test with different combinations of add-ons
test_cases.customer_impact: Silent failures, preventing customers from managing their accounts effectively

test_cases.issue_description: Existing customers are unable to apply promotional codes intended for new customers, despite receiving emails with valid codes
test_cases.test_scenario: Test the application of promotional codes sent to existing customers via email, to ensure they are either valid for existing customers or clearly marked as 'new customers only'
preconditions: Existing customer account with associated email address
Promotional code email sent to existing customer
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the web portal with an existing customer account
Step 2: Attempt to apply a promotional code intended for new customers to an upgrade or purchase
Step 3: Verify the system's response to the promotional code application
Step 4: Check the email containing the promotional code for any restrictions or eligibility criteria
Step 5: Validate that the system's response matches the eligibility criteria stated in the email
test_cases.expected_result: The system should either allow the existing customer to apply the promotional code or clearly display an error message stating that the code is only valid for new customers, and the email should clearly indicate any restrictions on the code's use
test_cases.actual_issue: The system incorrectly displays 'code not valid' without providing clear information about the code's eligibility criteria, and the email does not clearly indicate that the code is only for new customers
edge_cases: Test with different types of promotional codes (e.g. percentage off, fixed amount off, free shipping)
Test with different customer account statuses (e.g. active, inactive, suspended)
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration and potential loss of business due to incorrect or unclear promotional code application process

test_cases.issue_description: Mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed
test_cases.test_scenario: Test device upgrade feature on Android devices with varying number of installed apps
preconditions: Android device with Total Wireless mobile app installed
More than 100 apps installed on the device
Device upgrade option available in the app
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the Total Wireless mobile app on an Android device
Step 2: Navigate to the device upgrade section
Step 3: Select a new device for upgrade
Step 4: Verify if the app crashes or throws an error
Step 5: Repeat steps 2-4 with different numbers of installed apps (e.g., 50, 100, 150)
test_cases.expected_result: The mobile app should allow device upgrade selection without crashing, regardless of the number of installed apps
test_cases.actual_issue: Mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed
edge_cases: Test with apps that consume high memory
test_cases.customer_impact: Core functionality unavailable on mobile, forcing customers to use alternative channels, leading to frustration and potential churn

test_cases.issue_description: Customer unable to disable auto-pay through mobile app when enrolled through website
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that a customer can disable auto-pay through the mobile app regardless of where they initially enrolled
preconditions: Customer has auto-pay enabled through the website
Customer has mobile app installed and logged in
test_steps: Step 1: Enable auto-pay for a test account through the website
Step 2: Log in to the mobile app with the test account credentials
Step 3: Navigate to 'Account Settings' then 'Payment Settings'
Step 4: Verify that the option to disable auto-pay is available and functional
test_cases.expected_result: The customer can successfully disable auto-pay through the mobile app
test_cases.actual_issue: The mobile app lacks the feature to disable auto-pay for customers who enrolled through the website
environmental_dependencies: Mobile device with latest app version
edge_cases: Test with multiple accounts and auto-pay enrollments
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration and inconvenience due to inability to manage their account features through their preferred channel
